summary: The Kerala Service Rules, comprising parts I, II, and III, came into effect on November 1, 1959, for the first two parts and November 1, 1956, for the third part, as per the rules outlined in the document.

Rule 2 of the Kerala Service Rules states that the rules in Part II regarding Travelling Allowance and the remaining rules apply to certain government employees, excluding those in contingent or work establishments, with specific conditions for employees who were in service on October 31, 1956, and those absorbed into government service on or after November 1, 1956.

The Kerala Service Rules Volume I Part I & II Eighth Edition 2016, issued by the Finance Department of the Government of Kerala, outlines rules and regulations regarding pay, leave, joining time, and other general scope matters as specified in Rules 1-2 of Chapter I.

The Kerala Service Rules amendment, specifically rules 2-3, states that travelling allowance rules in Part II of the Kerala Service Rules also apply to persons temporarily appointed to government service under Rule 9 of Part II of the Kerala State and Subordinate Service Rules.

Rule 3 of the Kerala Service Rules states that these rules do not apply to persons with special provisions made by law or agreement, and also allows the Government to exclude certain officers or classes of officers from the operation of these rules by notification in the Gazette.

An employee who entered government service on or after November 1, 1956, but was previously employed by a quasi-government or other institution governed by existing laws or rules, may opt to be governed by the Kerala Service Rules subject to conditions set by the Government.

The Kerala Service Rules amendment, specifically Rule 9 of Part II, allows the government to exclude certain officers or classes of officers from the operation of these rules and also does not apply to temporarily appointed personnel except as specified by the government.

The Kerala Service Rules amendment, specifically rules 3-7, states that direct recruits to ministers' personal staff are governed by special rules applicable to them, with the Kerala Service Rules applying to any matters not covered by those special rules.

According to Rule 4 of Part I, Chapter I of the Kerala Service Rules, if any doubt arises as to whether these rules apply to any person, the matter shall be referred to the Government and the decision of the Government shall be final.

According to Rule 5 of Part I, Chapter I of the Kerala Service Rules, nothing in the rules or any subsequent rules shall deprive a person of their rights or privileges entitled by law, contract, or agreement with the Government as of the rules' effective date.

According to Rule 6 of Part I, Chapter I of the Kerala Service Rules, existing government employees holding substantive posts are protected from disadvantageous changes to their conditions of service, including pay, leave, allowances, pension, and other matters, as applicable on the date the rules came into force.

The Kerala Service Rules amendment protects the conditions of service, including pay, leave, allowances, pension, and other matters, for persons holding substantive posts under the Government, ensuring that no changes can be made to their disadvantage without their consent.

The Kerala Service Rules amendment, specifically Rule 7, allows the Government to dispense with or relax the requirements of any rule under these rules if it causes undue hardship in a particular case, as per Government Order G O(P) No. 68/1965/Fin., dated 16/02/1965.

The Kerala Service Rules amendment, specifically Rule 8, allows the Government to make special provisions for conditions of service, pay, allowances, leave, and pension for particular posts through agreements with appointed individuals, which supersede existing rules to the extent specified in the agreement.

The Kerala Service Rules amendment pertains to Rule 9 of Part I, Chapter I, of the KSR document, with no additional details provided regarding the amendment order number, dates, or descriptive information.

The Kerala Service Rules amendment provides that for any matter not covered in an agreement, the provisions of these rules or rules made thereunder shall apply, as further detailed in Appendix I which includes a model form of agreement.

The Government may delegate certain powers conferred upon it by the Kerala Service Rules to its officers with exceptions including making rules, regulating compensatory allowances, determining standard rent, remitting leave and pension contributions for foreign service transfers, and permitting foreign service officers to receive pension or gratuity from foreign employers.

The Kerala Service Rules, specifically rules 10-11, state that no powers may be exercised or delegated without consulting the Finance Department, which can prescribe cases where its consent is presumed, and the Government reserves the power to modify or interpret these rules as needed.

An officer's claims to pay and allowances, leave, and pension are regulated by the Kerala Service Rules in force at the respective times they are earned, applied for, or when the officer resigns or is discharged from service.

The Kerala Service Rules amendment defines key terms used in the rules, including actual travelling expenses, apprentice, and audit officer, providing clarity on their meanings and applications within the government service.

The Kerala Service Rules amendment governs the leave and pension rules for persons covered under these rules, specifying that those on leave as of November 1, 1959, will come under the new leave rules after their initially sanctioned leave expires, with all subsequent leave extensions to be regulated by the new rules and no arrears paid or excess amounts recovered.
The Kerala Service Rules amendment pertains to Rule 12 in Chapter II of Part I, which provides definitions.

The Kerala Service Rules amendment defines an Audit Officer as the Head of the Office of Accounts and Audit subordinate to the Comptroller and Auditor General of India, regardless of their designation, as per Rule 12 of Part I, Chapter II of the KSR document.
The Kerala Service Rules amendment to Rule 12 in Part I, Chapter II, deletes the description of "Average Pay" as specified in sub-section 3A.
The Kerala Service Rules amendment, specifically Rule 12 in Part I, Chapter II, defines "Cadre" as the strength of a service or part of a service sanctioned as a separate unit.

The Kerala Service Rules amendment pertains to Rule 12, which defines Compensatory Allowance as an allowance granted to meet personal expenditure necessitated by special circumstances in duty performance, including Travelling Allowance.

The Kerala Service Rules amendment, specifically Rule 12, defines the competent authority in respect of any officer as the authority to which power has been delegated under these rules, or, in the absence of specific delegation, the authority vested with the power to appoint such officer by the State Government.

According to Rule 12 of Part I, Chapter II of the Kerala Service Rules, a day is defined as a calendar day beginning and ending at midnight, with an absence from headquarters of up to 24 hours considered as one day regardless of the start and end times.

According to Rule 12 of Part I, Chapter II of the Kerala Service Rules, duty is defined as including service as a probationer or apprentice followed by confirmation, joining time, and any specially ordered course of instruction or training undergone by an officer.
The Kerala Service Rules amendment pertains to Rule 12 in Chapter II of Part I, and notes that a student, stipendiary or otherwise, who is entitled to be appointed is subject to certain conditions.

The Kerala Service Rules amendment, specifically Rule 12, outlines the conditions under which an officer can be considered as being on duty, including periods of confirmation, joining time, training, departmental examinations, and other specified circumstances.

According to Kerala Service Rules amendment Rule 12, the interval between a government servant's return from leave, training, foreign service, or previous appointment and their assumption of duties shall be treated as "duty" with entitlement to pay, provided the delay does not exceed admissible joining time, and avoidable delays may render authorities liable for excess expenditure.

A Kerala Service Rules amendment, specifically Note 6 under an unspecified section and rule, states that when a government servant is deputed by the government to participate in a civil service tournament, certain provisions apply, although the details of the amendment, including the effective date and order number, are not specified.

The Kerala Service Rules amendment, specifically Rule 12, addresses liable delay in posting orders and excess expenditure, while also deeming participation in certain civil service tournaments and coaching camps as duty, with a note explaining the term "Civil Service Tournament" and its effective date of July 1st, 1980.

The Kerala Service Rules amendment, specifically Rule 12, defines "fee" as a recurring or non-recurring payment to an officer from a source other than General Revenues, excluding unearned income and income from literary, cultural, or artistic efforts not aided by service-acquired knowledge, as per orders dated 05/05/1982 and 28/02/2007.

According to Rule 12 of Part I, Chapter II of the Kerala Service Rules, Foreign Service is defined as service in which an officer receives pay with government sanction from any source other than the Consolidated Fund of India or a State.
The Kerala Service Rules amendment pertains to Rule 12 in Part I, Chapter II of the KSR document, which describes general revenues of Kerala as including the Consolidated Fund.

According to Rule 12 of Part I of the Kerala Service Rules, foreign service is defined as service in which an officer receives pay with government sanction from any source other than the Consolidated Fund of India or a state.
The Kerala Service Rules amendment to Rule 12 defines General Revenues of Kerala as including the Consolidated Fund, Contingency fund, and Public Account, while excluding revenues of Local Funds.
The Kerala Service Rules amendment defines "Government" as the Government of Kerala, as stated in Rule 12 of Part I of the KSR document.
The Kerala Service Rules amendment pertains to Rule 12, which deals with gratuity, as referenced by the description "(12) Gratuity.- (See Pension)".

The Kerala Service Rules amendment, specifically Rule 12 as outlined in Appendix II, defines Heads of Departments to include officers declared as such by the Government and any other authority delegated with these powers.

According to Rule 12 of the Kerala Service Rules, a holiday is defined as either a day prescribed or notified by or under section 25 of the Negotiable Instruments Act, 1881, or a day on which a particular government office is ordered to be closed for transaction of government business via a gazette notification.

The Kerala Service Rules amendment, specifically Rule 12, defines honorarium as a recurring or non-recurring payment granted to an officer from the General Revenues of the State as remuneration for special work of an occasional or intermittent character.

The Kerala Service Rules amendment defines "Joining Time" as the time allowed to an officer to join a new post or travel to or from a station to which they are posted, as outlined in Rule 12 of Part I of the KSR document.

The Kerala Service Rules amendment defines Last Grade Service as service in any post included in the Kerala Last Grade Service, which was constituted by special rules published on March 8, 1966, and amended over time, and also includes all other posts carrying the lowest scale of pay.

Kerala Service Rules Part I, Rule 12, stipulates that when calculating periods, the total number of days in each calendar month should be determined first, followed by the calculation of any odd number of days, with periods in calendar months ending on the last day of the month.
The Kerala Service Rules amendment, specifically rule number 17, defines Leave Salary as the monthly amount paid by the Government to an officer on leave.

The Kerala Service Rules amendment defines "Lien" as an officer's title to hold substantively a permanent post to which they have been appointed substantively, either immediately or after a period of absence, as stated in Rule 18 of Part I of the KSR document.

The Kerala Service Rules amendment defines "Local Fund" as revenues administered by bodies under government control, including those with sanctioned budgets, posts, and benefits, as well as revenues of specially notified bodies.

The Kerala Service Rules defines a Ministerial Officer as an officer of a subordinate service with entirely clerical duties or any other class of officer specially defined as such by general or special government orders, as per Rule 20 of Part I of the KSR.

The Kerala Service Rules amendment defines a month as a calendar month, specifying that in calculations involving months and days, complete calendar months are counted regardless of the number of days they contain.

The Kerala Service Rules amendment pertains to the Kerala Last Grade Service, which includes posts with the lowest scale of pay and those declared by the Government as part of the service, as published and amended since its initial issuance under G.O.(P) 82/Public (Rules) Department on March 8, 1966.

The Kerala Service Rules amendment under Rule 12 provides guidelines for calculating periods in calendar months and days, including how to handle corresponding days, leap years, and broken periods, with examples illustrating the calculation of various timeframes.

According to Rule 22 of Part I, Chapter II of the Kerala Service Rules, an officer is considered to be officiating in a post when they perform the duties of a post on which another person holds a lien, and the appointing authority may also appoint an officer to officiate in a vacant post with no existing lien holder.

According to Rule 23 of Part I, Chapter II of the Kerala Service Rules, "pay" refers to the monthly amount drawn by an officer, excluding special pay or personally qualified pay, sanctioned for their held post.
The Kerala Service Rules amendment pertains to Part I, Chapter II, Rule 12, and is related to definitions.

The Kerala Service Rules amendment, specifically Rule 23, defines "pay" as the monthly amount drawn by an officer, comprising substantive or officiating pay, personal pay, special pay, and other emoluments classified as pay by the Government.
According to Rule 24 of Part I, Chapter II of the Kerala Service Rules, the term "Pension" includes "gratuity" and "Death-cum-retirement gratuity", except when used in contrast to these terms.
The Kerala Service Rules amendment defines a permanent post as a position with a definite rate of pay sanctioned without a time limit, as stated in Rule 25 of Part I, Chapter II of the KSR.

The Kerala Service Rules amendment defines personal pay as additional pay granted to an officer to prevent loss of substantive pay due to pay revisions or reductions, or in exceptional circumstances for other personal considerations, with cases under the latter category requiring referral to the Finance Department and meeting a high standard of exceptionality.

According to Rule 27 of Part I, Chapter II of the Kerala Service Rules, "Presumptive Pay of a Post" refers to the pay a government servant would be entitled to if they held the post substantively and performed its duties, excluding special pay unless they perform or discharge the associated work or responsibility.

The Kerala Service Rules amendment defines key terms related to government servants, including "pay" and "probationer", with detailed notes and explanations to clarify their meanings and applications in various scenarios.
The Kerala Service Rules amendment pertains to Rule 12 in Chapter II of Part I, which provides definitions.

The Kerala Service Rules amendment defines Public Conveyance as a train, steamer, bus, boat, or other conveyance that regularly conveys passengers, as stated in Rule 29 of Part I, Chapter II of the KSR document.

The Kerala Service Rules amendment, specifically rule 30 in Part I, Chapter II, defines the terms "qualify" and "count" as relating to qualification and counting for pension from the General Revenues or for leave of absence.

The Kerala Service Rules amendment defines Special Pay as an addition to emoluments granted due to additional responsibilities, arduous work, or extra duties, which may count towards pay fixation on promotion if drawn continuously for at least three years, except in cases of tenure posts or deputation.
The Kerala Service Rules amendment, specifically Rule 32 under Part I and Chapter II, defines Subsistence Allowance as a monthly grant for officers not receiving pay or leave salary.

The Kerala Service Rules amendment defines substantive pay as the pay to which an officer is entitled, excluding special pay, personal pay, or other emoluments classed as pay by Government under specific rules, as outlined in Rule 33 of Part I, Chapter II of the KSR document.

The Kerala Service Rules amendment defines various terms related to an officer's pay and position, including substantive pay, temporary post, time-scale of pay, and identical time-scales, and provides notes on the calculation of average pay and conditions for certain types of pay.

The Kerala Service Rules amendment, specifically Rule 12, explains that an employee's pay is determined by their position in the cadre or class, not the post they hold, and provides a formula for calculating average pay for gazetted appointments on time-scales of pay.

The Kerala Service Rules amendment, specifically Rule 12, provides a formula to calculate average pay for non-gazetted posts on time scales of pay, taking into account minimum and maximum pay, period of rise, average age at entry and retirement, with average retirement age assumed to be 55 unless special circumstances dictate otherwise.

The Kerala Service Rules amendment outlines a formula to calculate the average cost of appointments in a lower grade where everyone is ultimately promoted to a higher grade, using variables such as minimum pay, pay just before promotion, and other factors to determine the average pay.

The Kerala Service Rules amendment outlines the formula for calculating the average cost of appointments in a lower grade, including the calculation of average pay based on minimum pay, pay before promotion, period of rise, average age at entry and promotion, and government decisions regarding higher time-scales of pay.

According to Rule 36 of Part I, Chapter II of the Kerala Service Rules, transfer refers to the movement of an officer from one headquarter station to another to take up a new post or due to a change in headquarters.

Kerala Service Rules amendment number 37 defines Travelling Allowance as an allowance granted to cover expenses incurred while travelling for public service, including conveyance maintenance allowances, and updates the expressions "road mileage" and "mileage allowance" as per Government Decision.

Kerala Service Rule 13 stipulates that an officer with a noticed defect may not be transferred to a different office without a new medical certificate, unless exempted under specific conditions, including recruitment through competitive examination, temporary appointments, or re-employment after retirement, and also requires medical certificates for promotions from non-qualifying service or re-employment after resignation.

The Kerala Service Rules amendment outlines the requirements and procedures for medical certificates for government service appointments, including when they are necessary, the authority to decide on their requirement, and the rules governing medical examinations for candidates recruited to government service.
According to Kerala Service Rules Part I Chapter III Rule 13, an officer declared unfit on medical examination who prefers an appeal should be retained in service until the case is finally decided.

A government servant appointed temporarily on the basis of a medical certificate or without one may need to obtain a fitness certificate from a higher medical authority, and if found unfit, can appeal for a second examination and continue in service until a verdict is reached.

According to Rule 13 of Part I, Chapter III of the Kerala Service Rules, if a request for further medical examination is denied, the services of the officer in question should be terminated immediately.

According to Kerala Service Rules amendment Rule 13, when a candidate is deemed unfit, they must be immediately notified and informed that any appeal, along with a medical certificate if applicable, must be submitted within one month of receiving the Medical Officer's findings.

The Kerala Service Rules amendment pertains to Rule 13 in Part I, Chapter III, which addresses the scenario where no appeal is filed by a candidate or government servant within one month of receiving findings.

The Kerala Service Rules amendment outlines procedures for handling candidates or government servants declared unfit for service by a Medical Officer, including rejection notification, appeal processes, and termination protocols.

The Kerala Service Rules amendment, specifically rules 13-14, outlines the procedures for medical examinations of candidates or government servants, including the requisition process and the appeal procedure, stating that the appointing authority shall request a medical examination and that no appeal can be made against adverse findings of a Medical Officer in an appeal case.

The Kerala Service Rules amendment, specifically rules 13-14, outlines the requirements for certificates of physical fitness for government service entry, including the acceptable medical practitioners and the process for issuing and appealing medical certificates.

According to Rule 13A of Part I, Chapter III of the Kerala Service Rules, new recruits are required to produce a duly filled Form No 15 for registration in the Service and Payroll Administrative Repository for Kerala at the time of joining duty.

The Kerala Service Rules amendment, specifically Rule 14, states that an officer's whole time is at the disposal of the government paying them and they may be employed as required without claim for additional remuneration, as per orders dated 07/06/1963 and amended on 25/09/2009 with effect from 24/04/2007.

According to Rule 14 of the Kerala Service Rules, every officer is required to attend office punctually, and for every three days of late attendance without permission, they will forfeit one day's casual leave, with the computation of forfeiture based on the calendar year and ignoring late attendance of less than three days at the end of the year.
According to Rule 14 of Part I, Chapter III of the Kerala Service Rules, no other kind of leave except casual leave shall be forfeited for late attendance without permission.

The Kerala Service Rules amendment states that the forfeiture of a day's casual leave is calculated with respect to the calendar year and late attendance without permission for less than three days at the end of a calendar year will be ignored.

According to the Kerala Service Rules amendment, no type of leave except casual leave can be forfeited for late attendance without permission, and disciplinary action may be taken under the Kerala Civil Services rules against officers with no available casual leave to forfeit.

The Kerala Service Rules amendment introduces Rule 14A, which treats an officer's unauthorized absence due to strike participation as "Dies-Non", making them ineligible for pay and allowances and disqualifying the period from earned leave, but still counting it towards increment and half pay leave purposes.
Rule 14A of the Kerala Service Rules has been amended to be deemed effective as of January 10, 2002.

According to Kerala Service Rule 15, no two officers can hold the same permanent post simultaneously, an officer cannot hold multiple permanent posts except temporarily, and an officer cannot be appointed to a post where another officer already holds a lien.

Kerala Service Rules amendment to Rule 15 was made through two orders, initially by G O(P) No.593/1970/Fin. dated 20/08/1970 and later modified by insertion of G O(P) No. 212/2005/Fin. dated 11/05/2005.
The Kerala Service Rules amendment pertains to General Conditions of Service as outlined in Rules 16-18 of Part I, Chapter III of the KSR document.

According to Rule 16 of Part I, Chapter III of the Kerala Service Rules, an officer substantively appointed to a permanent post acquires a lien on that post and relinquishes any prior lien held on another post, unless otherwise specified in the rules.

According to Kerala Service Rules amendment, specifically Rule 17 in Part I, Chapter III, an officer holding substantively a permanent post retains a lien on that post unless it is suspended under Rule 18 or transferred under Rule 20.

According to Rule 17 of the Kerala Service Rules, an officer who is substantively appointed to a permanent post acquires a lien on that post and retains it under various circumstances, including while performing duties, on foreign service, holding a temporary post, on leave, under suspension, or under training, unless their lien is suspended or transferred under specific conditions.

The Kerala Service Rules amendment outlines the conditions under which the government may suspend an officer's lien on a permanent post, including appointment to a post outside their cadre, provisional appointment to a post with another officer's suspended lien, transfer to foreign service, or transfer to another cadre with expected absence of at least three years.

Rule 18 of the Kerala Service Rules governs the suspension and revival of an officer's lien on a post, outlining conditions under which a lien may be suspended, such as appointment to a higher post in a different cadre or foreign service, and specifying when a suspended lien revives, including when an officer ceases to hold a lien on a specified post or returns from leave, with provisions for filling the post substantively and acquiring a provisional lien.
The Kerala Service Rules amendment pertains to Part I, Chapter III, rules 18-21, and outlines general conditions of service, specifically noting considerations for officers on transfer.

According to Kerala Service Rules amendment in Chapter III, Part I, rules 18-21, an officer's lien on their permanent post cannot be suspended if they are transferred outside their cadre and are due to retire on superannuation pension within three years of the transfer.

An officer's lien on a post cannot be terminated without their consent if it would leave them without a lien or suspended lien on a permanent post, except in certain cases where the competent authority may refuse confirmation or retention in a permanent post outside their cadre unless they request termination of their lien.

According to Rule 20 of the Kerala Service Rules, the Government has the authority to transfer the lien of an officer who is not performing their duties to another permanent post in the same cadre, subject to the provisions of Rule 21.

The Kerala Service Rules amendment, specifically rule 21, states that the Government may transfer an officer to another post, with certain exceptions and conditions, including provisions related to pay and lien on a permanent post.

Rule 18 of Part I, Chapter III of the Kerala Service Rules states that an employee who is substantively appointed to a post with less pay than their permanent post, except in cases covered by Rule 58, would be affected by this rule.

According to Rule 12 of Part I, Chapter III of the Kerala Service Rules, nothing in clause (a) of this rule or clause (18) of Rule 12 prevents the transfer of an officer to a post where they would hold a lien if it had not been suspended under Rule 18.

According to Kerala Service Rules Part I Chapter III Rule 21-22A, an officer may be required to subscribe to certain funds as prescribed by government order, with a note clarifying that permanent transfers from a higher to lower scale in anticipation of post abolition are not considered transfers under this rule.

According to Rule 22 of the Kerala Service Rules, an officer may be required to subscribe to a provident fund or similar scheme, with options for alternative subscriptions, including a state life insurance policy for those who entered service before August 19, 1976, and continued subscription to the Family Benefit Scheme for officers on deputation or foreign service.

Any person entering Government Service in Kerala on or after August 19, 1976, and under 50 years old, must subscribe to a State Life Insurance policy within one month of joining, continuing until they leave service, as per an amendment that came into effect on April 5, 1999.

When an employee in Kerala Service moves to a higher pay range, they must take additional policy within 2 years, unless they are 45 years or older at the time of the transition, as per Rules 22A-22C of the Kerala Service Rules.

Any person entering Kerala Government service on or after September 1, 1984, and under 50 years old must enroll in the Group Insurance Scheme within a year and continue subscribing until they leave government service, with officers on deputation or foreign service responsible for arranging payment, as per an amendment deemed effective July 6, 2002.
An officer who wants prior service counted for benefits upon entering government service must apply within five years of entry, as per Rule 22C of the Kerala Service Rules.

The Kerala Service Rules amendment, as per various government orders including G O(P) No. 83/1980/Fin., G O(P) No. 511/2004/Fin., and G O(P) No.229/2012/Fin, dictates that government servants must subscribe to a determined service until they cease to be in government service, with the amendment deemed effective from April 5, 1999, and further modified with effect from December 16, 2008.

Government servants must apply for service benefits within five years of entering government service, with certain exceptions and time limits applying to officers already in service, particularly those nearing retirement, as per Kerala Service Rules amendment effective November 6, 2006.

According to Rule 23 of the Kerala Service Rules, an officer's pay and allowances are effective from the date they assume their post duties and cease when they stop discharging those duties, with exceptions for specific cases such as training or instruction courses.

The Kerala Service Rules amendment outlines the regulations regarding pay and allowances for officers who are promoted, transferred, or assume new duties, including the effective dates of such changes, the eligibility for monetary benefits, and the conditions under which officers can draw pay without joining a new post.

The Kerala Service Rules amendment, specifically Chapter III, Appendix III, of Part I, pertains to Government Decision No. 1, which addresses questions regarding the authority competent to accept a resignation and related circumstances.

The Kerala Service Rules amendment outlines the procedure for accepting resignations from government servants, specifying that the appointing authority is competent to accept resignations, except in certain circumstances such as when the officer is engaged in important work or under suspension, and provides guidelines for handling such situations.

The Kerala Service Rules amendment outlines the procedures and considerations for accepting a government servant's resignation while under suspension, including examining the merits of the disciplinary case, determining the effective date of resignation, and deciding whether to count leave towards notice periods.

The Kerala Service Rules amendment outlines the procedures for resignation, including the authority to accept or refuse resignation, permit withdrawal of resignation, and re-employment after condoning the period of break, with specific guidelines on concurrence requirements, pension eligibility, and pay fixation.

According to Kerala Service Rules amendment Rule 24, an officer shall be removed from service after five years of continuous absence from duty, unless the Government determines otherwise due to special circumstances, as per orders G O(P) No 98/1965/Fin dated 22/03/1965 and G O(P) No 82/1966/Fin dated 03/03/1966.

An officer shall be removed from service after five years of continuous absence from duty, following the procedure laid down in the Kerala Civil Services Rules, except in cases covered by Rule 24A, with this amendment effective as of December 16, 1983.

According to Kerala Service Rule 24A, an officer who takes leave without allowances for employment abroad or within the country for a total of twenty years and fails to return to duty immediately after the leave expires will have their service terminated, with this rule applying to all relevant cases on or after December 16, 1983.

The Kerala Service Rules amendment pertains to Chapter IV, specifically rules 25-26, which address pay exceptions, including personal pay granted under certain circumstances as defined in Rule 12 (26).

According to Rule 25 of Part I, Chapter IV of the Kerala Service Rules, an officer's pay cannot be increased beyond the sanctioned amount for their post without government sanction, except in cases of personal pay granted under specific circumstances defined in Rule 12 (26) (a).

The Kerala Service Rules amendment, specifically Rule 26, governs the pay of an officer undergoing training, allowing the Government to authorize payment of their substantive appointment pay, a lower rate, or officiating appointment pay, with specific conditions and exceptions for reservists of the Defence Services and clarification on key terms.

The Kerala Service Rules amendment clarifies that the pay of an officiating appointment refers to the substantive or officiating pay an officer would have drawn but for undergoing training, and includes various emoluments such as basic pay, special pay, personal pay, dearness pay, dearness allowance, and house rent allowance, as per G O(P) No 434/1965/Fin dated 17/11/1965.

According to Rule 27 of Part I, Chapter IV of the Kerala Service Rules, rules 28 to 37 regarding time-scale of pay generally apply, except for any time-scale sanctioned by the Government with specially sanctioned terms that may be inconsistent with these rules.

The Kerala Service Rules amendment, specifically Rule 28 under Part I, Chapter IV, regulates the initial substantive pay of an officer appointed to a time-scale post based on their lien status on a permanent post.

The initial substantive pay of an officer appointed substantively to a post on a time-scale of pay is regulated based on their previous experience and lien status, with specific provisions for counting previous service towards initial fixation of pay and increment in certain circumstances.

Rule 28 of the Kerala Service Rules states that for officers serving in ex-cadre posts, their service will count from the date their junior is promoted and the benefit will be limited to the period they would have held the post in their parent cadre, with specific conditions applying to substantive appointments to higher time-scales of pay.

The Kerala Service Rules amendment, specifically Rule 28A, states that when an officer is promoted or appointed to a higher-paying post, certain conditions apply regarding their initial pay, as outlined in Part I, Chapter IV of the rules.

When an officer is promoted to a post with a higher time-scale of pay, their initial pay will be fixed at the next stage above their notional pay in the lower scale, and they can opt to fix their pay on the date of promotion or a later date, with their next increment due after one year from the fixation date.

The Kerala Service Rules amendment, specifically Rule 28A, outlines the procedure for fixing the initial pay of a government servant promoted to a higher post, including considerations for previous experience and potential anomalies, with various effective dates and substitutions applied through subsequent government orders.

The Kerala Service Rules amendment under Rule 34, Part I, states that if a senior officer's pay is lower than a junior officer's pay in a higher post on the same scale, the anomaly will be removed by refixing the senior officer's pay to match the junior officer's, subject to certain conditions outlined in government orders G O(P) No. 348/1975/Fin and G O(P) No. 710/1970/Fin.

Rule 28A of the Kerala Service Rules states that to remove anomalies in pay, junior and senior officers in the same cadre with identical posts and pay scales can have their pay refixed if the junior officer's pay is higher, with the senior officer's pay refixation effective from the date of the junior officer's pay refixation, and subsequent increments and confirmations adjusted accordingly.

The Kerala Service Rules amendment, specifically rule 28A, states that for a government servant confirmed in a post with retrospective effect, their pay refixation will be revised, with any overpayments first set off against arrears and then waived, effective from February 3, 1962, as per Government Order No. 24/1965/Fin dated January 13, 1965.

The Kerala Service Rules amendment, specifically Rule 28A, states that refixation of pay in a higher officiating post is not allowed during a period of bar on increment, but in cases where the bar is without cumulative effect, notional refixation can be given with monetary benefits applied after the bar period expires.

According to Kerala Service Rules amendment Rule 28A, increments barred with or without cumulative effect in a lower substantive officiating post are not reckoned for pay fixation in a higher time-scale, except that barred increments without cumulative effect can be granted notionally for fixation and monetarily after the bar period expires.
The Kerala Service Rules amendment revises Rule 28A in Part I, Chapter IV, as per Ruling No. 5, with the description noting it is a revision of an existing rule.

Rule 28A of the Kerala Service Rules allows for notional grant of barred increments for pay fixation and monetary benefits after the bar period expires, with specific provisions and exemptions outlined for retrospective confirmation, revision of scales of pay, and officiating officers appointed to higher posts.

The Kerala Service Rules amendment outlines rules for pay fixation when an individual is appointed to a higher post, including permissible fixation with reference to previous pay in certain circumstances, such as regular capacity appointments or provisional appointments under specific rules, but not in cases of sequential provisional appointments to higher posts.

According to Rule 9 of the Kerala State and Subordinate Service Rules, an employee who is appointed to a higher post after being appointed to a lower post by the Service Commission under the same rule is not eligible for pay fixation in the higher post based on their pay in the lower post.

A person provisionally appointed to a higher post in the same service under Rule 31 or to a post in another service under Rule 9 of the Kerala State and Subordinate Services Rules is not eligible for pay fixation based on their initial provisional pay, according to Rule 31 of the Kerala Service Rules.
The Kerala Service Rules amendment states that decisions 1, 3, 4, and 5 are deemed to have taken effect from February 3, 1962, the date the rule came into force.

The pay drawn by an officer in an ex-cadre post can be counted for purpose of initial fixation of pay on promotion in the parent department, as per various government orders, including G O(P) No. 475/1990/Fin., G O(P) No. 06/1965/Fin., and G O(P) No. 580/1970/Fin., dated September 25, 1990, January 4, 1965, and August 13, 1970, respectively.

According to Rule 28A of Part I, Chapter IV of the Kerala Service Rules, an employee who is appointed to the parent department from an ex-cadre post is not eligible for the benefit of refixation of pay as they lose connection with the ex-cadre post.

The Kerala Service Rules amendment states that an officer reverted to their parent department to a post with a lower scale of pay than their previous ex-cadre post will not be eligible for the benefit of pay drawn in the ex-cadre post for initial fixation purposes.
